questions.answer_description:
When you export a report, the data is temporarily stored in a unique Azure Storage area in the Microsoft cloud before it's downloaded to your local computer.
To download the report from the Azure Storage Area, you need an export key.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/export-a-content-search-report

questions.answer_description:
Box 1:
If you copy the file from OneDrive to your internet connected computer, you can open the document for up to 30 days. This is because the ג€Number of days the content is validג€ setting is set to 30 days.
Box 2:
If you email the document to a user outside your organization, the user cannot open the document. To open the document, the user would need to be added to the Users list and assigned permission. With the configuration in the exhibit, only the user listed in the Users list and the creator of the document can open the document.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/configure-policy-protection

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains a user named User1.
You need to ensure that User1 receives Microsoft 365 feature and service updates before the updates are released to all users.
What should you do in the Microsoft 365 admin center?

discussion.content:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/manage/release-options-in-office-365?view=o365-worldwide#set-up-the-release-option-in-the-admin-center

- In the admin center, go to the Settings > Org Setting, and under the Organization profile tab, choose Release preferences.

- To enable targeted release for some people in your organization, select Targeted release for selected users, then select Save changes.

Selected Answer: C
Seen before in other questions; Set release option, I think to semi-anual for the test users and current branch or anual for the others
Mail Flow would make sense for any NEW emails, but does not address existing ones, so it would have to be a label situation.
C for sure!

Selected Answer: C
My first thought was eDiscovery but guess you could apply a label based on a custom sensitivity type that uses a keyword.

comments.content: It can be done by: Create Labels-->Auto-apply a label in Label policies, you can specify words. Therefore C is correct.

discussion.content: We can create a mail flow policy, set bcc and preserve the email in another mailbox.
the others option not make sense
What kind of label & label policy?

choices.A: From the Exchange admin center, start a mail flow message trace.
choices.B: From the Security & Compliance admin center, start a message trace.
choices.C: From the Security & Compliance admin center, create a label and label policy.
choices.D: From the Exchange admin center, create a mail flow rule.

questions.answer_description:
When you configure conditions for a label, you can automatically assign a label to a document or email. In this case, we would create a label to label all email messages that contain the word ProjectX. We would then create a label policy to preserve a copy of all message that have the label assigned.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/information-protection/configure-policy-classification

As we speak, this feature is being replaced by communication compliance policies. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/communication-compliance?view=o365-worldwide 
MyAnalytics: The MyAnalytics Network page shows how many people you actively connect with in the last month and gives you suggestions on how to improve connections with your most important contacts, such as your manager or your direct reports.

Communication and compliance policy from compliance center full fill this request.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/supervision-policies?view=o365-worldwide#:~:text=Supervision%20policies%20in%20Microsoft%20365,party%20communications%20in%20your%20organization.

questions.answer_description:
Supervision policies in Office 365 allow you to capture employee communications for examination by designated reviewers. You can define specific policies that capture internal and external email, Microsoft Teams, or 3rd-party communications in your organization.
You create supervision policies in the Compliance center. These policies define which communications and users are subject to review in your organization and specify who should perform reviews.
If you want to reduce the amount of content to review, you can specify a percentage of all the communications governed by a supervision policy. A real-time, random sample of content is selected from the total percentage of content that matches chosen policy conditions.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/securitycompliance/supervision-policies
